articles.title: Sho Miyazaki
articles.contents:
Welcome
Sho Miyazaki is a data scientist interested in legislative
redistricting, financial markets, and rugby football.
He is a LL.B. candidate in the Faculty of Law in Keio University,
studying political science (major), Japanese literature and arts
(minor), and statistics.
After studying at Harvard College as a visiting student, he is now
very motivated to study applied statistics, and wants to enroll in
Ph.D. Program in Quantitative Social Science.
He is also affiliated with the Algorithm-Assisted Redistricting
Methodology (ALARM) Project and Greenmantle.



47-Prefecture Redistricting Simulations





Comprehensive project to simulate alternative legislative redistricting
plans of House of Representatives for all 47 prefectures in Japan in the
2020 redistricting cycle.


 Explore the
project and data »

articles.contents:
47-Prefecture
Redistricting Simulations
(with Kento Yamada, Rei Yatsuhashi, and Kosuke Imai). 2022.
GitHub, Dataverse

BibTeX
@misc{miyazaki202247-prefecture,
  author = {Miyazaki, Sho and Yamada, Kento and Yatsuhashi, Rei and Imai, Kosuke},
  title = {47-Prefecture Redistricting Simulations
},
  doi = {https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/Z9UKSH},
  url = {https://alarm-redist.github.io/japan/}
  year = {2022}
}

Abstract

The goal of the 47-Prefecture Simulation Project is to generate and
analyze redistricting plans for the single-member districts of the House
of Representatives of Japan using a redistricting simulation algorithm.
In this project, we use a redistricting simulation algorithm to generate
redistricting plans that both limit the number of split municipalities
and minimize the voting weight disparity (一票の格差) within each
prefecture. Our simulations are designed to comply with the
redistricting rules that the Council abides by. We will start with the
19 prefectures subject to redistricting and plan to expand the scope of
our research to all 47 prefectures.

Abstract
Part I: A case study on the impact of correlated ETF fund flows on
stock price movements and what seems to have happened when the
decade-long trend stopped.
Part II: Measuring the impact of material, dynamic, and correlated
ETF fund flows.

articles.contents:
Data Science / Applied
Statistics
Introduction to
Quantitative Social Science
Professor Kosuke
Imai (Harvard University)
University of Tokyo, Summer 2022
Course Assistant
This is an undergraduate and graduate introductory level course on
data analysis in social sciences.

About
Would universal health insurance improve the health of the poor? Do
patterns of arrests in US cities show evidence of racial profiling? What
accounts for who votes and their choice of candidates?
This course will teach students how to address these and other social
science questions by analyzing quantitative data. The course introduces
basic principles of statistical inference and programming skills for
data analysis.
The goal is to provide students with the foundation necessary to analyze
data in their own research and to become critical consumers of
statistical claims made in the news media, in policy reports, and in
academic research
Interest-based Negotiation
Negotiation I and II
(交渉学 I and II)
Professor Jiro
Tamura (Keio University)
Keio University, Fall 2021
Teaching Assistant
This is an undergraduate introductory level course on interest-based
negotiation with active-learning.

About
Negotiation is a systematically organized methodology to overcome
conflicts and effectively reach an agreement. In this course we will
cover topics such as negotiation strategies based on logical thinking,
handling cognitive biases due to emotions and heuristics, methodology
for creating decision branches for effective consensus building,
effective management of negotiation processes, multi-party negotiation,
negotiation based on game theory, and methodology of conflict management
used to resolve global conflicts and disputes. In addition to the
lectures, students will actively work on practical exercises such as
group works and role-play simulation.
